header_summary:
Ava Chow announced the availability of Bitcoin Core version v28.1rc1 release candidate binaries for community testing, with the source code available on [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/v28.1rc1). This version introduces updates, fixes, and enhancements detailed in the preliminary release notes found on [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/v28.1rc1/doc/release-notes.md), marking a significant milestone in Bitcoin Core development.

Antoine Riard detailed a new transaction-relay jamming attack on bitcoin time-sensitive contracting protocols, specifically affecting lightning channels. This attack, emphasizing its significant financial requirement for execution, highlights vulnerabilities in the Bitcoin network's transaction selection and propagation mechanisms. Proposed mitigation strategies focus on measures for lightning node operators and off-chain protocol developers, suggesting further research into comprehensive solutions at the base-layer level. The detailed timeline from initial findings to public disclosure underscores the collaborative effort in addressing this vulnerability.

In a separate thread, discussions by harding and fiatjaf revealed vulnerabilities and advancements in blockchain and lightning network technologies. They discussed old versions of major Lightning Network implementations being susceptible to attacks that could misappropriate channel funds, with mitigation efforts focusing on protocol and transaction relay protocol updates. Additionally, fiatjaf presented a breakthrough using APO as an overridable CTV in blockchain transactions, despite identifying a vulnerability within the system's design, showcasing both the potential and challenges in evolving blockchain technology [GitHub](https://github.com/nbd-wtf/soma).

Lastly, HubertusVIE explored Bitcoin's viability as a real-world currency, attributing its primary obstacle to economic rather than technical factors, such as volatility. The proposed solution involves a Bitcoin-based Chaumian ecash layer to enhance fungibility without altering Bitcoin's core protocol, suggesting a strategic approach to overcome economic hurdles for mainstream Bitcoin adoption as detailed in an ongoing series at [https://blog.bitcr.org/p/the-bitcoin-dilemma-store-of-value-or-medium-of-exchange](https://blog.bitcr.org/p/the-bitcoin-dilemma-store-of-value-or-medium-of-exchange).

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.1 Release Candidate 1 Available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v28.1rc1 release candidates are now available for testing.
- Preliminary release notes for the new version outline updates, fixes, and enhancements.
- This testing phase ensures the version's stability before its final release across the Bitcoin network.

recent_posts.title: Full Disclosure: "Transaction-Relay Throughput Overflow Attacks against Off-Chain Protocols"
recent_posts.summary:
- The report analyzes a new transaction-relay jamming attack on bitcoin protocols, especially lightning channels.
- It details two attack variants, "high overflow" and "low overflow," their execution, and possible impacts.
- Proposed mitigation strategies focus on actions by lightning node operators and off-chain developers.

recent_posts.title: Disclosure: irrevocable fees---stealing from LN using revoked commitment transactions
recent_posts.summary:
- LN vulnerability allowed miners to misappropriate up to 98% of a channel's funds.
- Updates for Eclair, LDK, and LND were released to mitigate this vulnerability.
- Mitigation efforts include adopting static commitment fees and requiring protocol upgrades.

recent_posts.title: CTV, APO, CAT activity on signet
recent_posts.summary:
- A notable advancement in blockchain with APO as an overridable CTV occurred in Q2 2023.
- Soma, a spacechain toy, was used for practical demonstration and is on GitHub.
- A vulnerability in the free spending mechanism was found, highlighting experimentation.

recent_posts.title: op_CAT vs op_CTV vs XMR
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's adoption faces economic, not technical, challenges, notably volatility.
- A Bitcoin-based Chaumian ecash layer could make it a practical cash form.
- Initial exploration of these concepts is available in a series on [blog.bitcr.org](https://blog.bitcr.org/p/the-bitcoin-dilemma-store-of-value-or-medium-of-exchange).

active_posts.title: Adding New BIP Editors
active_posts.summary:
- Luke's difficulty managing the BIPs necessitates more BIP editors with full responsibilities.
- New BIP editors must align on numbering schemes and have a history in Bitcoin development.
- Kanzure and RubenSomsen are recommended for their potential to improve BIP management.

active_posts.title: Covenants Support - Bitcoin Wiki
active_posts.summary:
- A new initiative seeks Bitcoin developers' opinions on covenant proposals via a Bitcoin wiki draft.
- The wiki aims to facilitate consensus for soft forks, similar to SegWit, and invites more contributions.
- It emphasizes developer discussions on OP_CTV to improve covenant pools and coinjoin implementations.

active_posts.title: Difficulty in emulating "weaker" OP_SUCCESS and why it should be a real opcode
active_posts.summary:
- OP_SUCCESS opcode simplifies Bitcoin's fraud proof scripting, allowing immediate success marking.
- Rusty Russell highlights its utility and the complexity of traditional script emulation.
- Simplifying script development with such opcodes could make fraud proofing more accessible.

active_posts.title: Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
active_posts.summary:
- The analysis highlights Bitcoin protocol vulnerabilities, suggesting improvements for network security and performance.
- It proposes solutions for the timewarp vulnerability and risks from small transactions to enhance stability.
- Community debate emerges around block size reduction, reflecting concerns over network scalability and efficiency.

active_posts.title: Libbitcoin for Core people
active_posts.summary:
- Eric Voskuil showcased Libbitcoin's IBD outperforming Bitcoin Core, with speeds up to 15 times faster.
- Libbitcoin's efficiency stems from an event-based system, concurrent operations, and a structured database approach.
- Despite its speed, Libbitcoin faces challenges like unimplemented DoS protection and outdated cryptographic libraries.

active_posts.title: PPLNS with job declaration
active_posts.summary:
- Development of an SV2 extension is underway, enhancing mining pool payout transparency and fairness.
- The extension enables miners to select transactions, offering control over mining jobs and fee structures.
- The project, still in development, seeks reviews and contributions for refinement, detailed in linked GitHub documents.

today_in_history_posts.title: Planned Obsolescence
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Version Satoshi:0.13.1 is the most used Bitcoin node, with 38.97% of nodes.
- Over 30% of Bitcoin Core nodes run on versions older than 0.13.0.
- Introducing planned obsolescence for node versions could simplify development and protocol.

today_in_history_posts.title: LN without SegWit: less efficient or less secure?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The writer questions SegWit's role in Lightning Network's feasibility.
- Concerns about Level 2's security versus Level 3's user experience are raised.
- Outsourcing channel monitoring is considered as a solution for Level 2's security issues.

today_in_history_posts.title: Warnet + Increase Tx Relay Rate
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Accurate mainnet replication requires analyzing transaction rates and network configuration effects.
- Tests show operating 250 nodes with Docker is feasible, aiming for a closer mainnet approximation.
- Desired outcomes focus on identifying key metrics, such as bandwidth and CPU usage changes.
